chapterTitle: Introduction to Valuation:The Time Value of Money

columns.text: In this exercise, we are presented with a scenario in which we receive $10,000 in 2 years and we plan to invest it at a 9% rate until we obtain $60,000. We want to calculate for how long should we invest to meet our goal.

To calculate this we need to use the formula of Present Value (PV) and rearrange it to obtain the value of time for each case.

$$\begin{aligned}

PV & = \frac{FV}{(1+r)^t}\\
\\
t &=\dfrac{ \ln \left( \dfrac{FV}{PV} \right)}{\ln(1+r)}

\end{aligned}$$

*Where:*

- FV is the future value 
- t are the times the rate is applied
- r is the rate applied

We are going to obtain the years (t) we need to wait to meet our goal, however, we need to account for the first two years as well if we want to know how long we need to wait from now (T).

$$ T = t + 2

Next, we will calculate the years we need to wait to meet our goal since we start investing. 

$$\begin{aligned}
t &=\dfrac{ \ln \left( \dfrac{\$60,000}{\$10,000} \right)}{\ln(1+0.09)}\\
\\
&= \boxed{20.79}

\end{aligned}$$

We need to wait for **20.79** years from year 2.
